heading: mp3 cutting into music sales?
subheading: a decline in music purchases last year by 15- to 24-year-olds has the music industry "puzzled." one clue may be mp3 and the "free entertainment center" that is the internet.
author: wired news report
text: in a survey released this week, the recording industry association of america claims that mp3 files may be a contributing factor to the decline in music purchases by 15- to 24-year-olds.the survey, which accounts for trends in genre, gender, age, buying outlets, and other variables, concludes that there has been a drop in music purchases among younger customers, contrasted by significant growth among those age 35 and older."the continuing drop-off in the proportion of purchases accounted for by 15- to 24-year-olds (32.2 percent in 1996 versus 28 percent in 1998), once the mainstay of the market, is puzzling. potentially the rise of the internet as a free entertainment center, and the accompanying availability of free mp3 music files, could be contributing factors."read more mp3 coverage.- - - - - -the riaa says it doesn't have anything against mp3.in a wired news interview wednesday, hilary rosen, the chief executive of the riaa, said "my problem with mp3 is not when it's given away, but when it's stolen. to me, there's a big difference between artists being on a site like mp3.com or goodnoise wanting promotion, making the decision to give it away. there's a big difference between that and an ftp site that has 1,000 stolen songs on it."the riaa described the internet as a "free entertainment center," yet noted that online music sales tripled in the last year, accounting for 1.1 percent of total sales. that piece of the pie is equivalent to the number of purchases made from television offers, the riaa said. the size of the domestic sound recording industry in 1998 was $13.7 billion.the annual consumer profile is conducted by taylor nelson sofres intersearch, and is based on a survey of 3,000 music buyers across the country.
